item.title: Javascript
item.content:encoded:
Javascript was created by Brendan Eich in 10 days in the May of 1995, by combining features from several quite languages:

  • Java - syntax
  • Scheme - inspiration the use of functions as first-class objects
  • Self - prototypal inheritance
  • Perl - regular expressions

Mixing all these influences have led to Javascript as a language. JavaScript is standardized through the ECMAScript specification (often abbreviated simply as ES), beginning with ES1 in 1997 and ES2 in 1998.

ECMAScript

http://www.ecma-international.org/ecma-262/6.0/

Javascript versions

https://www.w3schools.com/js/js_versions.asp

Compatibility ES6

https://kangax.github.io/compat-table/es6/

Hello world

javascript

    console.log("Hello world!");

python

    print "Hello world"

java

    System.out.println("Hello World");

Strings

Strings

    const name = "Ernesto";
    console.log(name);

concatenation

    const name = "Ernesto";
    const lastName = "Martinez";
    console.log(name + " " +lastName);
    console.log(`${name} ${lastName}` );

Booleans

    const flag = true;
    console.log(flag);
    console.log(!flag);

Numbers

In javascript there is just one type of number, Number;

    const age = 32;
    console.log(32);

Control Flow

If we want to change the flow of our app, the if else statement is really useful.

    const isRainyToday = true;
    if (isRainyToday) {
        console.log("raining heaviiy");
    } else {
        console.log("sunny day");
    }

Loops

    let peopleAtClassroom = 0;
    peopleAtClassroom = peopleAtClassroom + 1;
    peopleAtClassroom = peopleAtClassroom + 1;
    peopleAtClassroom = peopleAtClassroom + 1;
    peopleAtClassroom = peopleAtClassroom + 1;
    peopleAtClassroom = peopleAtClassroom + 1;
    peopleAtClassroom = peopleAtClassroom + 1;
    console.log(peopleAtClassroom);

while

    let peopleAtClassroom = 0;
    while (peopleAtClassroom < 10) {
      peopleAtClassroom = peopleAtClassroom + 1;
    }
    console.log(peopleAtClassroom);

shorcuts

    let peopleAtClassroom = 0;
    peopleAtClassroom = peopleAtClassroom + 1;
    peopleAtClassroom += 1;
    peopleAtClassroom++;
    ++peopleAtClassroom;
    console.log(peopleAtClassroom);

for

    let peopleAtClassroom = 0;
    for (let i = 0; i <= 10; i++) {
      peopleAtClassroom++;
    }
    console.log(peopleAtClassroom);

Functions and Scope

example 1

    function addFour(value) {
      return value + 4;
    }
    const finalResult = addFour(5);
    console.log(finalResult);

example 2

    const myHomeCity = "Guadalajara";
    const myHomeState = "Jalisco";
    const myHomeCountry = "Mexico";
    
    function printYourHome(city, state, country) {
      console.log(`You are from ${city}, ${state} ${country}.`);
    }
    
    printYourHome(myHomeCity, myHomeState, myHomeCountry);

Scope

example 1

    function sum(number1, number2) {
      const someVariable = "you can't see me outside this function";
      return number1 + number2;
    }
    sum(10, 12);
    console.log(someVariable);

example 2

    let peopleAtHome = 0;
    for (let i = 0; i <= 10; i++) {
      peopleAtHome++;
    }
    console.log(i);

Builtins

Lots of functions exist for strings, arrays, etc, in javascript

Objects and Arrays

We can group data through objects, this is really useful because we can have { keys: values }.

const person1 = {
    name: 'Gabriel',
    lastName: 'Martinez'
    country: 'Mexico',
    address: 'Insurgentes norte avenue'
};
const person2 = {
    name: 'Ernesto',
    lastName: 'Escobar'
    country: 'Guatemala',
    address: 'Siempre viva avenue'
};

Using objects and functions are really powerful.

    function filterByCountry(person) {
        if(person.country === 'Guatemala'){
            console.log('you are from Guatemala, buddy');
        } else {
            console.log('you are from Mexico, so good!');
        }
    }

Context

the value of this is determined by how a function is called (runtime binding)

    var test = {
      prop: 'hello moto',
      func: function() {
        return this.prop;
      },
    };

Global Context

In the global execution context (outside of any function), this refers to the global object

    console.log(this);
    console.log(this === window);
    // Node
    console.log(global.process);
    console.log(this.process);
    // Browser
    console.log(this.alert);
    console.log(window.alert);

Function Context

Inside a function, the value of this depends on how the function is called.

    function f1() {
      return this;
    }
    
    // In a browser:
    f1() === window; // true 
    
    // In Node:
    f1() === global; // true
    
   // An object can be passed as the first argument to call or apply and this will be bound to it.
var obj = {a: 'Custom'};

// This property is set on the global object
var a = 'Global';

function whatsThis() {
  return this.a;  // The value of this is dependent on how the function is called
}

whatsThis();          // 'Global'
whatsThis.call(obj);  // 'Custom'
whatsThis.apply(obj); // 'Custom'

Object method

    var o = {
      prop: 37,
      f: function() {
        return this.prop;
      }
    };

    console.log(o.f()); // 37

https://repl.it
